head.title: Late Comeback Falls Short, And Liberty Loses to Shock

hedline.hl1: Late Comeback Falls Short, And Liberty Loses to Shock

abstract.p: Detroit Shock defeats New York Liberty, 67-63; photo (M)

block.p: Richie Adubato, the Liberty coach, was musing about his team's poor shooting in the second half of its last several games.
Despite a furious comeback attempt in the last minute of last night's game at Madison Square Garden, the Liberty lost to Detroit, 67-63, as the demons roared to life once more.
Richie Adubato, the Liberty coach, was musing about his team's poor shooting in the second half of its last several games.
Despite a furious comeback attempt in the last minute of last night's game at Madison Square Garden, the Liberty lost to Detroit, 67-63, as the demons roared to life once more.
Shooting 39.7 percent for the game, the Liberty committed 21 turnovers and took only 11 free throws, converting 9. The Shock made 25 of 35 free throws.

''Except for when we came back at the end, we didn't really play well enough to win the game,'' Adubato said. ''We break down on offense a lot, and we can't do that. Every time down the floor, someone makes a mistake.''
Claudia Maria das Neves led all scorers with a career-high 16 points for Detroit (5-5). Tamika Whitmore scored 14 to lead the Liberty (4-6).

Tari Phillips's 3-pointer brought the Liberty within 65-63 with 7.2 seconds left before Dominique Canty made two free throws for Detroit. With six seconds remaining, Phillips stepped out of bounds as she brought the ball upcourt.
The Shock was called for a five-second violation trying to inbound the ball, but the Liberty's Crystal Robinson missed a 3-pointer at the buzzer.
The scrambling, scrappy comeback faded like the flash from a camera, leaving a dark, brooding image in the Liberty minds.

''This is very frustrating,'' said Teresa Weatherspoon, who finished with 7 points and 7 assists for the Liberty. ''I don't think anyone's been inconsistent as consistently as we have. I have no idea why. We can't get it done.''

The Liberty (4-6) did not score a field goal against the Shock (5-5) for 7 minutes 40 seconds. But the Liberty went on a sparkling 10-2 run to start the second half, vaulting it to a 40-33 lead with 16:46 to go.

The Shock, however, went on a 6-0 run to snatch a 47-46 lead with 8:32 left. Robinson floated in for a slow-motion jumper and converted a foul shot, to tie the score. But das Neves fired a 3-pointer to give the Shock a 3-point lead.

A teetering shot by Sue Wicks hopped around the sides of the rim before falling through, bringing the Liberty within 1 with 4:39 to go. But the Shock scored the next 8 points for a 58-51 lead with 2:11 remaining.
After a 10-2 run by the Shock to open the game, neither team could scrape together more than three baskets in a row as both slipped and skittered all over the court in the first half.
The Shock stumbled to nine turnovers; the Liberty had 12.
